_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Liquid level controls; pressure vessels built to ASME code; pipes welded by certified welders

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The Tree Top, Inc. ammonia refrigeration system uses pure Ammonia (anhydrous) as the refrigerant.  Given the quantity handled, Ammonia (anhydrous) is considered an extremely hazardous substance by the EPA.  Many of the properties that make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant, also require that policies and procedures be implemented to protect employee and public health and safety in the event of a chemical emergency.  It is the policy of Tree Top, Inc. to be in compliance with all applicable Federal, State and local rules and regulations.

Safety at our facility is dependent on the safe handling of Ammonia (anhydrous).  While the design of the facility incorporates a multitude of safety devices, safe handling procedures combined with the appropriate training of our personnel and contractors are key requirements to maintain safety at our facility.

We have a written Process Safety Management (PSM) plan that complies with the regulations stipulated by WAC 296-67-017 and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119.  A critical component of this plan are the Emergency Action and Emergency Response Plans that were developed for compliance with the emergency response provisions of WAC 296-62-3112 and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120(q).  The Emergency Action and Response Plans include pre-emergency planning and coordination activities with outside response agencies.  This enables those who manage emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events.

2.  Facility Description And Substances Handled:

Tree Top, Inc. is a juice and fruit product manufacturing and storage facility.  Manufacturing and storage requires the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the processed products prior to their distribution to our customers.  The refrigeration process uses Ammonia (anhydrous) as the refrigerant.  Access to the facility is restricted to authorized and trained employees, visitors, ven

dors and contractors.  

The regulated substance handled at this facility is Ammonia (anhydrous).

The ammonia refrigeration system actual inventory is 17,000 pounds and the maximum intended inventory is 22,894 pounds of Ammonia (anhydrous).  There is no standby or backup inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) kept on site.

3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program And Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

Tree Top, Inc. complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention regulation and with all applicable Federal, State and local regulations.  The design and construction of this facility was in accordance with published standards, tests, industry standards and all applicable regulations at the time of construction.

Tree Top, Inc.'s written Process Safety Management Plan incorporates many policies, procedures and plans to ensure the safe operation and maintenance of this facility.  Plan elements essential to the safe operation of the refrigeration system include employee participation, process hazard information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, hot-work permits, management of change, incident investigation, emergency  planning and response, and compliance audits.  This plan will be reviewed at least annually and updated as required to comply with Federal, State and local regulations.

Training is provided to ensure that each employee or contractor involved in operating the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system has been trained in an overview of the process, operating and maintenance procedures, and safety considerations.  This training uses guidelines developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and the Refrigerating Engineers and Technician's Association (RETA).  Only qualified maintenance and contractor personnel operate and/or maintain the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system.  This minimizes the chances of an inadvertent er

ror in the operation or maintenance that could lead to a release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  

4.  5-Year Accident History:

There have been no reportable accidents or incidents involving the Ammonia (anhydrous) rfefrigeration system during the past 5 years.

5.  Emergency Response Program:

Tree Top, Inc. has written Emergency Action and Response Plans that were developed to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to protect employee and public health and safety in the event of an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  This plan complies with the provisions of the WISHA Emergency Response Regulation WAC 296-62-3112 and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120(q).  The Emergency Action and Response Plans include pre-emergency planning and coordination with outside response agencies.  This enables those who would respond to emergencies at this facility to plan and train together prior to an emergency response.  These plans have also been reviewed with the Prosser Fire Department.

Pre-planning has identified potential accidental release scenarios for the Ammonia (anhydrous) for this facility.  These scenarios are used by the Prosser Fire Department, and the facility and Tri-City Hazmat Teams, to prepare for the unlikely event of a release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  The refrigeration system also has backup prevention systems to keep process upset conditions from becoming Ammonia (anhydrous) emergencies.  If an emergency should occur, the following response personnel, equipment, facilities and systems are in place:

Unified Incident Command 
Emergency Notification, Evacuation and Accountability
Site and Tri-City Hazardous Materials Teams
Personal Protective Equipment and Training
Coordination With The Prosser Fire Department 

The procedures for obtaining external emergency assistance have been formally established with the Prosser Fire Department and Moon Security.  

All Tree Top, Inc. personnel are trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in

the event of a facility emergency.  Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with response procedures and identify any continuous improvement requirements.

6.  Planned Changes To Improve Safety:

This facility expanded the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system in 2006.  All refrigeration system components meet the design specifications of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's (IIAR) recommendations for equipment, design, and installation of Ammonia (anhydrous) mechanical refrigeration systems.  All pressure vessels were built to comply with the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), ASME Boliler and Pressure Vessel, and Pressure Vessel Codes.  Any future modifications to the design, installation, maintenance or operation of the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system will be made compliant with the applicable Federal, State and local regulations.

All Tree Top, Inc. personnel are trained to fulfill their designated roles and responsibilities in an emergency.  Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with potential emergency scenarios involving the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system.
